thread.title: Theatre Bizarre gala sets table for tonight's big event
thread.title_full: Theatre Bizarre gala sets table for tonight's big event

author: freep.com
title: Theatre Bizarre gala sets table for tonight's big event
text:
MORE On Friday, 450 guests indulged in a special sneak peak of Theatre Bizarre at Detroit’s Masonic Temple, which shot flames into the sky all night long as a forewarning that the event dubbed the "greatest masquerade on earth" was imminent.
The sold-out Grand Preview Gala was a colorful swirl of extravagant masks — ranging from feathered to beaked to Venetian — and masquerade-like costumes. The $250 ticket included valet parking, open bar, strolling dinner (with chicken florentine pinwheels and carrot kebobs), and seemingly never-ending decadent trays of dessert.
It also included an array of custom curated entertainment for Friday night only that featured a 12-piece orchestra playing an original score composed by goth-rock band Bauhaus member David J and orchestra leader Joshua James, a burlesque performance by Roxi D’Lite, fire-breathers (and eaters), and a number of additional sideshow acts.
The Theatre Bizarre Preview Gala offered 450 guests a sampling of the 5,000 person Saturday night event at the Masonic Temple on Friday, Oct. 16, 2015. (Photo: John Froelich, Special to the Free Press)
As the evening progressed, the gala’s procession continued to shift floors, moving into the lower levels of the Masonic Temple for dinner and back up again for the after party. But unlike tonight’s main event—which encompasses eight floors—only a few were utilized Friday.
While Friday may have come with the perks of complimentary dinner and drinks, tonight’s sold-out event is the bigger and more lavish party. Open to 4,500 people, Theatre Bizarre will kick into full swing with upped production — like a ghost train to shuffle guests around — and a fresh batch of musical entertainment, including 20-some bands and 10 DJs.
John Dunivant, the creative head behind Theatre Bizarre, says attendees can expect one thing: “Danger.”
Theatre Bizarre
Doors at 6:30 tonight
$85 (sold out)
Masonic Temple, Detroit
theatrebizarre.com
Theatre Bizzare's black tie masquerade gala in Detroit hosted an eclectic mix of curious first timers and Theatre Bizarre veterans in an upscale atmosphere on Friday, Oct. 16, 2015. (Photo: John Froelich, Special to the Free Press)
